qas.question: What profesional roles from secular law does the Catholic Church also employ?
What is not present in the Catholic legal system as compared with non-religious law?
What is the English equivalent of the term abbreviated by J.C.B.?
What is the Latin term for Licentiate of Canon Law?
What is not fully developed in the Catholic Church?
What kind of binding forces does the Catholic Church have that are not in most secular jurisdictions?

plausible_answers.text: the J.C.B. (Juris Canonici Baccalaureatus, Bachelor of Canon Law,

qas.question: What is one of the non-academic degrees in Canon law?

plausible_answers.text: degrees in civil law or theology

qas.question: What are usually not pre-request for studying canon law?

context: It is a fully developed <b5_0>legal system<b5_0/>, with all the necessary elements: courts, <a0_0>lawyers, judges<a0_0/>, a fully articulated legal code principles of legal interpretation, and coercive penalties, though it lacks <a1_0><b6_0>civilly-binding<b6_0/> force<a1_0/> in most secular jurisdictions. The academic degrees in canon law are <b7_0>the J.C.B. (<a2_0>Juris Canonici Baccalaureatus<a2_0/>, <a3_0>Bachelor of Canon Law<a3_0/>,<b7_0/> normally taken as a graduate degree), J.C.L. (<a4_0>Juris Canonici Licentiatus<a4_0/>, Licentiate of Canon Law) and the J.C.D. (Juris Canonici Doctor, Doctor of Canon Law). Because of its specialized nature, advanced <b8_0>degrees in civil law or theology<b8_0/> are normal prerequisites for the study of canon law.
